what's the deal with 's in super old posts?

For mods that have been here a long time, what percentage of threads (obviously a rough guess) actually contain content that hasn't been posted before? You know... original content?

I imagine after awhile its like refreshing reddits frontpage; you know all the content just by glancing at it, but on occasion something new pops up to keep up your interest.

> 
> what's the deal with 's in super old posts?

This is due to the forum software we used to use, simple machines, vBulletin is not quite able to handle the different format.

> 
> For mods that have been here a long time, what percentage of threads (obviously a rough guess) actually contain content that hasn't been posted before? You know... original content?
> I imagine after awhile its like refreshing reddits frontpage; you know all the content just by glancing at it, but on occasion something new pops up to keep up your interest.

I'm not confident enough to put a number on it, but yes, after a certain amount of time, you do tend to notice that certain topics and ideas have a sort of "life cycle" where someone will start a forum thread on them, the thread becomes popular, then it starts to lose steam as most of the more active participants have already said their piece and move onto something else, whereupon the thread slips off the front page and the topic lies still until someone starts a new thread (or revives the old one, though we generally don't encourage people to do the latter frivolously past a certain point because information often becomes outdated).

(I've also been active on enough forums for long enough to know that that sort of phenomenon has existed much longer than Reddit has. Most forums tend to have certain major discussion trends that get rehashed and refined over time.)

I'm sorry if this has been asked before, but is there any reason why the sticky Forum Rules thread shows it's been "moved?"

> 
> I'm sorry if this has been asked before, but is there any reason why the sticky Forum Rules thread shows it's been "moved?"

Convenience, it saves a click when going to view the rules. There is only one rules thread (for the obvious reason of making them less tedious to edit), and we used to have a sticky thread in each subforum containing a link to the rules. So you'd have to click that thread, then click the link. Now we have a redirect in each subforum instead, clicking that redirect brings you right to the rules in one click.
